com.intel.util

Class LogManager

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.intel.util.LogManager

  • @ThreadSafe
public final class LogManager
extends java.lang.Object
    This utility class provides a wrapper around the Android Log class to simplify managing logging on an app-wide basis. This class automatically generates a log tag, prefixes log messages with the current thread name, prefixes log messages with the current class and method name, and handles String formats with ease. When given certain objects as String formats, such as Cursor, Array, Intent, or Bundle, this class knows how to stringify them in a useful manner instead of using the native toString() methods of these objects.

    Prior to calling any of the logging methods of this class, clients should call init(Context). Typically this call is made from either Application.onCreate() or ContentProvider.onCreate(). After init(Context) is called, the log tag is automatically generated by lowercasing the app's name and replacing whitespace with hyphens. If clients would like to override this behavior, they may add the string resource "com_intel_util_log_tag" to provide an explicit log tag.

    To capture logs and do something else with them, such as write them to disk, then clients may call setJavaLogger(Logger) to hook into the logging mechanism.

    Because logging is expensive, it is recommended that clients of this class strip out logging statements at compile time with ProGuard/DexGuard, with the exception of the always(String, Object...). The configuration would look like this: 

     -assumenosideeffects public class com.intel.util.LogManager {
     public static *** v(...);
     public static *** d(...);
     public static *** i(...);
     public static *** w(...);
     public static *** e(...);
 }

    • Method Detail

      • init

        public static void init(@NonNull
                        android.content.Context context)
        Initializes logging.

        This normally should be called once in Application.onCreate(). (It may also need to be called from ContentProvider.onCreate() due to the fact that ContentProvider objects are created before Application objects).

        Parameters:
        context - Application context.

      • always

        public static void always(@NonNull
                          java.lang.String msg,
                          @Nullable
                          java.lang.Object... args)
        Always log a message. Messages from this method are logged with the Log.INFO logging level

        This method should be used with discretion.

        Parameters:
        msg - message to log.
        args - to format into the String.

      • setJavaLogger

        public static void setJavaLogger(@Nullable
                                 java.util.logging.Logger logger)
        Configure LogManager to also send log messages to a standard Java logger.
        Parameters:
        logger - Logger to set. Passing null clears any previously set logger.

      • setExternalLogger

        public static void setExternalLogger(@Nullable
                                     LogManager.ExternalAsyncLogger logger)
        Configure LogManager to also send log messages to an external logger.
        Parameters:
        logger - Logger to set. Passing null clears any previously set logger.
